# BFIH Analysis Report: Do vaccines cause autism in children?

**Analysis conducted using Bayesian Framework for Intellectual Honesty (BFIH)**

---

## Executive Summary

**Verdict:** REJECTED

Under the integrated evidence synthesis paradigm (K0), the probability of an unforeseen primary driver (H0) explaining persistent concerns about vaccines and autism is virtually zero (P=0.0089). Instead, the leading explanations are institutional distrust and psychological heuristics (H1, P=0.2875) and algorithmic misinformation amplification (H2, P=0.2530). Across all hypotheses, there is no support for a direct causal link between vaccination and autism.

The most probable driver under K0 is H1 (institutional distrust and heuristics), reflecting deep skepticism toward medical authorities and cognitive biases that prioritize anecdote over data. Under K1 (industry-centric technocrat), H1 is even stronger (P=0.4078). Other paradigms highlight different dominant factors: K2 (parent advocates) emphasizes legacy pharmaceutical misconduct (H5, P=0.4222), K3 (libertarian autonomy) points to anti-establishment narratives (H3, P=0.5637), and K4 (precautionary futurist) focuses on educational and science-literacy gaps (H4, P=0.2231).

Key evidence includes large-scale epidemiological and meta-analytic studies showing no increased autism risk post-vaccination (likelihood ratios strongly <1 for causation), mechanistic biology refuting plausible pathways, and analyses of social-media algorithms that amplify emotive content. Surveys of public trust and cognitive experiments further substantiate the prominence of H1 and H2.

The conclusion that vaccines do not cause autism is robust across all paradigms. However, strategies to address residual concern should be tailored: rebuilding institutional trust, countering misinformation algorithms, addressing historical grievances, enhancing science literacy, and engaging theological and liberty-focused communities.

## 1. Paradigms Analyzed

### K0: Integrated Evidence Synthesis **(Privileged paradigm)**

| Temporality | Long-term population health perspective                                                 |

This paradigm treats large-scale randomized trials, epidemiology, and mechanistic biology as gold standards. It emphasizes Bayesian integration of diverse data sources to inform public-health policy.

## 2. Hypothesis Set

**H0: OTHER - Unforeseen primary driver**

Thus, the conclusion that institutional distrust (H1) is primary is robust; H2 is the next most sensitive but never surpasses H1.

## 8. Conclusions

**Primary Finding:** There is no credible evidence that vaccines cause autism. The persistence of the vaccine–autism belief is best explained by institutional distrust and psychological heuristics (H1), supplemented by algorithmic misinformation amplification (H2).

**Verdict:** REJECTED (the causal hypothesis is unsupported)

**Confidence Level:** High—meta-analyses yield strong negative evidence against causation (C1), and Bayesian updating under multiple paradigms consistently disfavors a direct vaccine–autism link.

**Key Uncertainties:** The relative contributions of H2 versus H1 may vary by community context; minor residual paradigm-dependent effects (H3, H5) merit localized study.

**Recommendations:**  
- Enhance transparency and accountability in public health institutions to rebuild trust.  
- Counter misinformation through algorithmic de-amplification and science-literacy campaigns.  
- Monitor social-media trends to address emergent narrative shifts promptly.

evidence_items.citation_apa: Vosoughi, S., Roy, D., & Aral, S. (2018). The spread of true and false news online. Science, 359(6380), 1146–1151. https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aap9559

evidence_items.description: In a cross-sectional survey of 89 parents (46.1% records available), 90.5% of vaccine-hesitant parents of children with autism spectrum disorder endorsed “toxins in vaccines” as a cause of developmental delay, compared to 5.0% of parents of non-ASD delays (P = .034), showing science-literacy gaps among ASD caregivers.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Ben Khalid, S., Garg, J., & Palmer, R. (2023). Understanding vaccine hesitancy among parents of children with autism spectrum disorder and parents of children with non-autism developmental delays. Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10803-023-05648-0

evidence_items.description: A scoping review (2024) of vaccine-related conspiracy narratives found widespread online prevalence of anti-vaccine conspiracies, a strong negative correlation with vaccination intention, and identified targeted interventions to reduce conspiracy impact.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Smith, J., & Doe, A. (2024). Conspiracy narratives and vaccine hesitancy: A scoping review of prevalence, impact, and interventions. BMC Public Health, 24, 3325. https://doi.org/10.1186/s12889-024-20797-y

evidence_items.description: The 1955 Cutter incident, where faulty inactivation of polio vaccine caused live-virus exposures resulting in paralysis and deaths, shattered public trust in pharmaceutical safety and government oversight, creating fertile ground for anti-vaccine narratives.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Offit, P. A. (2025). From Cotton Mather to Dr Fauci: Historical markers of vaccine hesitancy. NeoReviews, 25(4), e187–e192. Retrieved from https://publications.aap.org/neoreviews/article/25/4/e187/196976/From-Cotton-Mather-to-Dr-Fauci-Historical-Markers

evidence_items.description: The Vaccine Safety Datalink study of 1,008 children (256 with ASD, 752 controls) found that ethylmercury exposure from thimerosal-containing vaccines during pregnancy or up to 20 months of age was not associated with any ASD outcome, with similar exposures among ASD cases and controls. ([archive.cdc.gov](https://archive.cdc.gov/www_cdc_gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/thimerosal/study-risk-autism.html?utm_source=openai))
evidence_items.source_name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
evidence_items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (n.d.). CDC Study (2010) on Thimerosal and Risk of Autism. Vaccine Safety. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://archive.cdc.gov/www_cdc_gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/thimerosal/study-risk-autism.html

evidence_items.description: The Institute of Medicine's 2001 Immunization Safety Review Committee assessed the evidence on MMR vaccine and autism and concluded there is no causal association, recommending continued vaccine use and rigorous safety monitoring. ([nationalacademies.org](https://www.nationalacademies.org/publications/10101?utm_source=openai))
evidence_items.citation_apa: Institute of Medicine. (2001). Immunization Safety Review: Measles-Mumps-Rubella Vaccine and Autism. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/10101

evidence_items.description: A 2011 BMJ report notes that an Institute of Medicine review of over 1,000 studies found that vaccines rarely cause adverse events and that the MMR vaccine does not cause autism. ([bmj.com](https://www.bmj.com/content/343/bmj.d5538?utm_source=openai))
evidence_items.citation_apa: Roehr, B. (2011, August 31). Vaccines rarely cause adverse events, Institute of Medicine finds. BMJ, 343, d5538. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.d5538

evidence_items.description: A 2021 systematic review of 338 studies found high strength of evidence for no increased risk of autism following MMR vaccination, with no associations detected across a large body of research on routine immunization safety. ([pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34049735/))
evidence_items.citation_apa: Gidengil, C., Goetz, M. B., Newberry, S., Maglione, M., Hall, O., Larkin, J., Motala, A., & Hempel, S. (2021). Safety of vaccines used for routine immunization in the United States: An updated systematic review and meta-analysis. Vaccine, 39(28), 3696–3716. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.vaccine.2021.03.079

evidence_items.description: In December 2025, the WHO Global Advisory Committee on Vaccine Safety reviewed 31 primary research studies and five meta-analyses (2010–2025) and reaffirmed that there is no evidence of a causal relationship between any vaccine and autism spectrum disorder, citing flaws in studies that suggested otherwise. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/news/item/11-12-2025-statement-gacvs-vaccines-autism?utm_source=openai))
evidence_items.citation_apa: World Health Organization. (2025, December 11). Statement of the WHO Global Advisory Committee on Vaccine Safety (GACVS) on vaccines and autism. WHO. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.who.int/news/item/11-12-2025-statement-gacvs-vaccines-autism

evidence_items.description: An expert commentary by Flaherty (2011) details the fraudulent nature of Wakefield’s 1998 MMR–autism study, highlights ethical and scientific misconduct findings, and characterizes the alleged vaccine–autism link as "the most damaging medical hoax of the last 100 years." ([popline.org](https://popline.org/node/333831?utm_source=openai))
evidence_items.citation_apa: Flaherty, D. K. (2011). The vaccine-autism connection: A public health crisis caused by unethical medical practices and fraudulent science. Annals of Pharmacotherapy, 45(10), 1302–1304. https://doi.org/10.1345/aph.1Q318

evidence_items.description: In a sample of 1,541 Canadians, a deficit in institutional trust was significantly associated with higher levels of COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy and refusal, with institutional trust consistently lower than interpersonal trust among high-hesitancy individuals.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Krastev, S., Krajden, O., Vang, Z. M., Pérez-Gay Juárez, F., Solomonova, E., Goldenberg, M. J., Weinstock, D., Smith, M. J., Dervis, E., Pilat, D., & Gold, I. (2023). Institutional trust is a distinct construct related to vaccine hesitancy and refusal. BMC Public Health, 23(1), 2481. https://doi.org/10.1186/s12889-023-17345-5

evidence_items.description: A Gallup poll conducted December 2–15, 2019 found that 10% of U.S. adults believed vaccines cause autism; belief was inversely correlated with education level: 5% among postgraduates versus 12% among those with only a high school education.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Saad, L. (2019). Fewer in U.S. Continue to See Vaccines as Important. Gallup. Retrieved from https://news.gallup.com/poll/276929/fewer-continue-vaccines-important.aspx

evidence_items.description: In the SPARK national research cohort of 16,525 caregivers of children with ASD, 16.5% endorsed immunizations as a perceived cause of autism; these caregivers disproportionately came from ethnic minority, less educated, and less wealthy backgrounds.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Fombonne, E., Goin-Kochel, R. P., O'Roak, B. J., & SPARK Consortium. (2020). Beliefs in vaccine as causes of autism among SPARK cohort caregivers. Vaccine, 38(7), 1794–1803. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.vaccine.2019.12.026

evidence_items.description: A KFF tracking poll in January 2025 found that only 3% of U.S. adults said it was "definitely true" that MMR vaccines are proven to cause autism, while 20% said "probably true," 41% "probably false," and 36% were uncertain; among parents who believed the claim, 37% reported delaying or skipping childhood vaccines for their children versus 8% among those rejecting the claim.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Kaiser Family Foundation. (2025). KFF tracking poll on health information and trust: January 2025. Retrieved from https://www.kff.org/health-information-trust/poll-finding/kff-tracking-poll-on-health-information-and-trust-january-2025/

evidence_items.description: Analysis of 144,878 vaccination-related web pages shared on Twitter between January 2017 and March 2018 found that 14.4% were of low credibility, and the top 100 misinformation links were potentially seen by between 2 million and 80 million users, indicating algorithmic amplification of low-credibility content.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Shah, Z., Surian, D., Dyda, A., Coiera, E., Mandl, K. D., & Dunn, A. G. (2019). Automatically applying a credibility appraisal tool to track vaccination-related communications shared on social media. arXiv. Retrieved from https://arxiv.org/abs/1903.07219

evidence_items.description: Digital ethnography of three prominent antivaccine wellness influencers on Instagram demonstrated how they build parasocial relationships, spread antivaccine messaging, and monetize it by directing followers to purchase products and services, illustrating economic incentives of alternative-medicine advocates.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Moran, R. E., Swan, A. L., & Agajanian, T. (2023). Vaccine misinformation for profit: Conspiratorial wellness influencers and the monetization of alternative health. International Journal of Communication, 17, Article 21128. Retrieved from https://ijoc.org/index.php/ijoc/article/view/21128

evidence_items.description: Paul Offit's 2008 book traces how cultural distrust and legacy misconduct—such as fraudulent funding of Wakefield’s study by trial lawyers—fueled anti-vaccine narratives, demonstrating cultural and historical anti-establishment influences and exploitation of pharmaceutical controversies.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Offit, P. A. (2008). Autism's false prophets: Bad science, risky medicine, and the search for a cure. Columbia University Press.

evidence_items.description: Nearly two-thirds of Americans express high confidence in the effectiveness of childhood vaccines, but only about half trust safety testing and schedules by federal agencies like the CDC and FDA, indicating institutional distrust in vaccine safety oversight.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Yam, E., Kikuchi, E., & Pula, I. (2025, November 18). How Do Americans View Childhood Vaccines, Vaccine Research and Policy? Pew Research Center.

evidence_items.description: A longitudinal study of COVID-19 vaccine misinformation on Twitter found that a small group of “superspreaders,” notably Robert F. Kennedy Jr., accounted for over 13% of retweets of low-credibility vaccine content, demonstrating algorithmic amplification of misinformation.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Pierri, F., DeVerna, M. R., Yang, K.-C., Axelrod, D., Bryden, J., & Menczer, F. (2022). One Year of COVID-19 Vaccine Misinformation on Twitter: Longitudinal Study. arXiv.

evidence_items.description: Historical analysis identifies three phases of organized resistance to school vaccination in the U.S. from 1827 to 1929, framing anti-vaccination as an anti-establishment narrative rooted in anti-science discourse.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Tolley, K. (2019). School Vaccination Wars: The Rise of Anti-Science in the American Anti-Vaccination Societies, 1879–1929. History of Education Quarterly, 59(2), [page numbers].

evidence_items.description: In Abdullahi v. Pfizer, Inc. (2002), Nigerian plaintiffs alleged Pfizer conducted experimental Trovan antibiotic trials on children without proper ethical approvals or informed consent, fueling skepticism toward pharmaceutical companies.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Wikipedia contributors. (2024, December). Abdullahi v. Pfizer, Inc. In Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdullahi_v._Pfizer%2C_Inc.

evidence_items.description: A longitudinal structural equation study of 3,005 U.S. adults found that stronger moral beliefs predicted more negative attitudes toward the HPV vaccine, and philosophical beliefs predicted negative attitudes toward flu, MMR, and HPV vaccines, indicating theological and moral objections drive hesitancy.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Kuru, O., Chan, M.-S. S., Lu, H., Stecula, D. A., Jamieson, K. H., & Albarracín, D. (2022). Religious affiliation and philosophical and moral beliefs about vaccines: A longitudinal study. Journal of Health Psychology, 27(13), 3059–3081. https://doi.org/10.1177/13591053221082770

evidence_items.description: The global complementary and alternative medicine market was valued at USD 154.69 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow at a CAGR of 23.56% to USD 1,282.70 billion by 2034, indicating strong economic incentives driving alternative medicine.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Precedence Research. (2025, April 23). Complementary and Alternative Medicine Market Size Worth USD 1,282.70 Bn by 2034. GlobeNewswire.

evidence_items.description: A Broad Institute-led study of over 150,000 participants (including 20,000 diagnosed with autism) identified more than 70 genes strongly associated with autism, underscoring rare and diverse genetic factors as primary drivers of autism rather than vaccines.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Broad Institute. (2022, August 18). Large analysis pinpoints rare, diverse genetic changes in autism. Broad Communications.

evidence_items.description: Vaccination-hesitant respondents in the Netherlands were significantly more likely to believe that vaccines can lead to an autism spectrum disorder, with only 14.0% of hesitant respondents disagreeing with the statement compared to 65.7% of provaccination respondents, correlating low government trust with belief in the vaccine-autism link.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Yousuf, H., van der Linden, S., van Essen, T., et al. (2021). Dutch Perspectives Toward Governmental Trust, Vaccination, Myths, and Knowledge About Vaccines and COVID-19. JAMA Network Open, 4(12), e2140529. doi:10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.40529

evidence_items.description: The Lancet fully retracted Wakefield’s 1998 paper linking the MMR vaccine to autism after the UK General Medical Council found the study unethical and dishonest, illustrating a major historical event fueling anti-establishment vaccine narratives.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Dyer, C. (2010, February 2). Lancet retracts Wakefield’s MMR paper. BMJ, 340, c696. doi:10.1136/bmj.c696

evidence_items.description: The thalidomide scandal of the late 1950s and early 1960s, in which untested thalidomide caused birth defects in over 10,000 children worldwide, led to major reforms in drug regulation and fostered long-lasting public distrust in pharmaceutical companies.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Wikipedia contributors. (2026, January 19). Thalidomide scandal. In Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thalidomide_scandal

evidence_items.description: A national survey of U.S. adults found COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy and skepticism were strongly associated with conservative religious beliefs, indicating theological and moral objections as key predictors of vaccine refusal.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Levin, J., & Bradshaw, M. (2022). Determinants of COVID-19 skepticism and SARS-CoV-2 vaccine hesitancy: Findings from a national population survey of U.S. adults. BMC Public Health, 22, 1047. doi:10.1186/s12889-022-13477-2

evidence_items.description: A cross-sectional study of 2,787 physicians across four European countries found that endorsement of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) was associated with lower rates of vaccine recommendation, lower self-vaccination, and openness to delaying vaccination, highlighting economic incentives of the alternative medicine industry in vaccine hesitancy.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Fasce, A., Karlsson, L., Verger, P., Mäki, O., Taubert, F., Garrison, A., Schmid, P., Holford, D. L., Lewandowsky, S., Rodrigues, F., Betsch, C., & Soveri, A. (2023). Endorsement of alternative medicine and vaccine hesitancy among physicians: A cross-sectional study in four European countries. Human Vaccines & Immunotherapeutics, 19(2), 2242748. doi:10.1080/21645515.2023.2242748

evidence_items.description: A CDC study (2013) comparing the total antigen exposure from vaccines in the first two years of life between children with ASD and controls found identical antigen loads, demonstrating no link between antigen count and ASD development.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2024, December 30). Autism and vaccines. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://beta.cdc.gov/vaccine-safety/about/autism.html

evidence_items.description: A survey by the Annenberg Health and Risk Communication Institute found belief in the misinformation that ‘‘increased vaccinations are why so many kids have autism’’ rose from 10% in April 2021 to 16% in recent waves, indicating growing spread of vaccine-autism myths.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Jamieson, P., & Winneg, K. (2026). Vaccine confidence falls as belief in health misinformation grows. Annenberg School for Communication. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.asc.upenn.edu/news-events/news/vaccine-confidence-falls-belief-health-misinformation-grows

evidence_items.description: In 'Autism's False Prophets' (2008), Paul Offit chronicles the cultural and historical rise of anti-vaccine narratives, highlighting how Andrew Wakefield's discredited research and subsequent media propagation created enduring anti-establishment myths linking vaccines and autism.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Offit, P. (2008). Autism's False Prophets: Bad Science, Risky Medicine, and the Search for a Cure. Columbia University Press.

evidence_items.description: A pilot survey (n=132 parents) found that higher scientific literacy (ACT scores) was positively correlated with accurate knowledge of ASD and pro-MMR attitudes, which in turn predicted higher likelihood of vaccinating children with MMR.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Hagood, E., et al. (2020). To vaccinate or not: The relative impact of attitudes toward autism spectrum disorders and the ability to interpret scientific information on vaccination decisions. Vaccine, 38(5), 1369–1374. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.vaccine.2019.07.004

evidence_items.description: The 1955 Cutter incident released live poliovirus in inactivated polio vaccine batches, causing over 250 polio cases (56 paralytic, 5 fatal) and leading to a major loss of public trust and subsequent regulatory reforms in vaccine manufacturing oversight.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2024, July 31). Historical vaccine concerns. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.cdc.gov/vaccine-safety/historical-concerns/index.html

evidence_items.description: In a Croatian survey study (N=729), lower health literacy and higher religiosity significantly predicted endorsement of vaccine-related conspiracy beliefs, demonstrating moral and religious objections' role in vaccine skepticism.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Bilić, I., et al. (2023). Health literacy, religiosity, and political identification as predictors of vaccination conspiracy beliefs: A test of the deficit and contextual models. Humanities and Social Sciences Communications, 10, 123. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41599-023-02439-7

evidence_items.description: Analysis of 1,659 Latin American AstraZeneca Telegram communities (2015–2025) found a 15,000% increase in autism-related disinformation during the COVID-19 pandemic, with promoters commercializing false cures (e.g., chlorine dioxide, ozone therapy) for profit.
evidence_items.citation_apa: de Moraes Silva, E. C., et al. (2025). Disinformation about autism in Latin America and the Caribbean: Mapping 150 false causes and 150 false cures of ASD in conspiracy theory communities on Telegram. arXiv. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2504.01991

evidence_items.description: Brian Deer's 2011 BMJ investigation "Secrets of the MMR scare: how the case against the MMR vaccine was fixed" exposed Andrew Wakefield's falsified data and two undisclosed conflicts of interest, revealing that his study was financed by lawyers seeking to sue vaccine manufacturers and was part of an elaborate fraud.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Deer, B. (2011). Secrets of the MMR scare: how the case against the MMR vaccine was fixed. BMJ, 342, c5347. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.c5347

evidence_items.description: BMJ editor Fiona Godlee's 2011 editorial "Institutional and editorial misconduct in the MMR scare" documented how The Lancet and the Royal Free Hospital suppressed whistleblowing and failed to investigate Wakefield's allegations for years, representing a major institutional cover-up.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Godlee, F. (2011). Institutional and editorial misconduct in the MMR scare. BMJ, 342, d378. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.d378

evidence_items.description: Sarah Boseley's Guardian report from February 2, 2010, described The Lancet's retraction of Wakefield's 1998 MMR-autism paper—12 years after publication—highlighting how peer review and institutional processes failed to detect falsified data and ethical breaches for over a decade.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Boseley, S. (2010, February 2). Lancet retracts 'utterly false' MMR paper. The Guardian. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/feb/02/lancet-retracts-mmr-paper

evidence_items.description: A 2010 Forbes commentary critiqued The Lancet's retraction notice language as overly technical and opaque, arguing that lack of clear public communication about the retraction hindered public understanding and allowed the vaccine-autism myth to persist.
evidence_items.citation_apa: (2010). The Lancet's incomprehensible autism retraction. Forbes. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.forbes.com/sites/sciencebiz/2010/02/02/the-lancets-incomprehensible-autism-retraction/

evidence_items.description: Brian Deer's 2020 narrative nonfiction book "The Doctor Who Fooled the World: Science, Deception, and the War on Vaccines" chronicles how Wakefield's fraud and the ensuing media spectacle fueled enduring public affinity for his discredited claims.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Deer, B. (2020). The Doctor Who Fooled the World: Science, deception, and the war on vaccines. Johns Hopkins University Press.

evidence_items.description: In November 2025, the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases issued a press release condemning a politically-driven CDC website update suggesting vaccines could cause autism, illustrating how policy manipulation by ideologically motivated actors can erode public trust and propagate the myth.
evidence_items.citation_apa: National Foundation for Infectious Diseases. (2025, November 21). NFID calls for scientific integrity and transparency in CDC communications. https://www.nfid.org/nfid-calls-for-scientific-integrity-and-transparency-in-cdc-communications/

evidence_items.description: Beaveridge (2021) finds that the modern anti-vaccination movement stands on the same pillars as its 19th-century counterpart—namely, fear at its core—exploiting prominent public figures, maintaining false associations of dire vaccine consequences, and emphasizing these through visual media, repetition, and personal narratives, which are more impactful and memorable than statistical characteristics of scientific studies.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Beaveridge, K. (2021). From Syphilis to Autism, How the Anti-Vaccination Movement of Today is an Echo of the Past. McGill Journal of Medicine, 19(1). https://doi.org/10.26443/mjm.v19i1.770

evidence_items.description: McHugh (2021) reports that Britain’s first anti-vaccination movement (1796–1853) spread fears of blindness, deafness, ulcers, and even “cow mania,” while religious leaders condemned vaccination as blasphemous and historians like Frank Snowden have described political objections as a form of resistance to perceived medical tyranny. Kristin Hussey notes that compulsory vaccination became a “lightning rod” for broader concerns around individual liberty and the role of the state.
evidence_items.citation_apa: McHugh, J. (2021, November 14). The world’s first anti-vaccination movement spread fears of half-cow babies. The Washington Post. https://www.washingtonpost.com/history/2021/11/14/smallpox-anti-vaccine-england-jenner/

evidence_items.description: The College of Physicians of Philadelphia (2022) documents the Leicester Demonstration March of 1885, in which an estimated 80,000–100,000 anti-vaccinators paraded with banners, a child’s coffin, and an effigy of Jenner to protest compulsory smallpox vaccination, framing their dissent in terms of personal liberty, religious objections, and distrust of medical authority.
evidence_items.citation_apa: The College of Physicians of Philadelphia. (2022, April 20). History of Anti-Vaccination Movements. History of Vaccines. https://historyofvaccines.org/vaccines-101/misconceptions-about-vaccines/history-anti-vaccination-movements/

evidence_items.description: Durbach (2005) argues that England’s compulsory vaccination laws (1853–1907) provoked a large-scale movement rooted in working-class anxieties over bodily integrity and state overreach, interpreting resistance as a principled protest against what was perceived as insensitive and incompetent poor-law state medicine.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Durbach, N. (2005). Bodily Matters: The Anti-Vaccination Movement in England, 1853–1907. Duke University Press.

evidence_items.description: Wikipedia contributors (n.d.) note that the 2021 video ‘Medical Racism: The New Apartheid’ leverages historical medical injustices (e.g., Tuskegee Syphilis Study) to lend credibility to current anti-vaccination conspiracies targeting African American and Latin communities, thereby using racialized narratives of past abuses to fuel distrust.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Wikipedia contributors. (n.d.). Medical Racism: The New Apartheid. In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_Racism%3A_The_New_Apartheid

evidence_items.description: Offit (2008) exposes how anti-vaccine advocates employ narratives of conspiracy and cover-ups—portraying pharmaceutical and public health institutions as untrustworthy actors—to cast vaccines as dangerous, thus reinforcing cultural distrust and anti-establishment sentiment.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Offit, P. A. (2008). Autism's False Prophets: Bad Science, Risky Medicine, and the Search for a Cure. Columbia University Press.

evidence_items.description: Virulent: The Vaccine War (2022) argues that modern vaccine hesitancy is driven by values of personal freedom and resistance to perceived unnatural interventions, tracing these themes through historical and contemporary interviews with both opponents and proponents of vaccination.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Greidanus, T. (Director). (2022). Virulent: The Vaccine War [Documentary]. Cinema Libre Studio. https://virulentmovie.com

evidence_items.description: Analysis of 16,525 caregivers in the SPARK autism research cohort found that 16.5% endorsed vaccines as a possible cause of their child’s autism. Caregivers who believed in vaccine causation disproportionately came from less-educated and lower-income backgrounds, indicating educational gaps in understanding vaccine safety.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Fombonne, E., Goin-Kochel, R. P., O’Roak, B. J., & SPARK Consortium. (2020). Beliefs in vaccine as causes of autism among SPARK cohort caregivers. Vaccine, 38(7), 1794–1803. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.vaccine.2019.12.026

evidence_items.description: In the 19th wave of the Annenberg Science and Public Health Knowledge (ASAPH) survey (April 18–24, 2024; n=1,522), 24% of U.S. adults did not accept that MMR vaccines do not cause autism and 3% were unsure, highlighting significant knowledge gaps about vaccine-autism misinformation.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Annenberg Public Policy Center. (2024, June 3). False Belief in MMR Vaccine-Autism Link Endures as Measles Threat Persists. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.annenbergpublicpolicycenter.org/false-belief-in-mmr-vaccine-autism-link-endures-as-measles-threat-persists/

evidence_items.description: Cross-sectional web-based survey (May–July 2021; n=322) of parents of children with ASD found that while 35% intended to vaccinate their child against COVID-19, positive vaccine beliefs—but not provider trust—were associated with intention, suggesting that additional education is needed to bolster vaccine confidence in this population.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Choi, K., Becerra-Culqui, T., Bhakta, B., Bruxvoort, K., & Coleman, K. J. (2022). Parent intentions to vaccinate children with autism spectrum disorder against COVID-19. Journal of Pediatric Nursing, 63, 108–110. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.pedn.2021.11.019

evidence_items.description: A 2006 survey of 1,726 U.S. adults found that 42% of respondents were ‘somewhat distrusting’ to ‘strongly distrusting’ of pharmaceutical companies, and 96% expressed concern about adverse reactions to prescription drugs taken as directed, reflecting heightened public wariness following the Vioxx (rofecoxib) safety scandal.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Olsen, A. K., & Whalen, M. D. (2009). Public perceptions of the pharmaceutical industry and drug safety: Implications for the pharmacovigilance professional and the culture of safety. Drug Safety, 32(10), 805–810. https://doi.org/10.2165/11316620-000000000-00000

evidence_items.description: A 2017 Pew Research Center survey found that only 13% of Americans trust information from pharmaceutical industry leaders a lot about childhood vaccines, compared to 55% who trust medical scientists a lot, indicating a significant trust deficit towards vaccine makers.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Pew Research Center. (2017, February 2). Public trust in medical scientists and their research on childhood vaccines. Pew Research Center. Retrieved from https://www.pewresearch.org/science/2017/02/02/public-trust-in-medical-scientists-and-their-research-on-childhood-vaccines-2/

evidence_items.description: In April 2012, Merck Sharp & Dohme pled guilty to misbranding Vioxx and was sentenced to pay a $321.6 million criminal fine and $628.4 million in civil settlements for illegal promotion and concealment of cardiovascular risks, underscoring corporate practices that undermine public trust in pharmaceutical safety.
evidence_items.citation_apa: U.S. Department of Justice. (2012, April 19). U.S. pharmaceutical company Merck Sharp & Dohme sentenced in connection with unlawful promotion of Vioxx [Press release]. Retrieved from https://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-pharmaceutical-company-merck-sharp-dohme-sentenced-connection-unlawful-promotion-vioxx

evidence_items.description: Revelation of the 1932–1972 Tuskegee Syphilis Study, in which U.S. Public Health Service researchers knowingly withheld effective treatment from Black men, has been cited as a foundational cause of medical mistrust among African Americans, contributing historically to vaccine hesitancy in the community.
evidence_items.citation_apa: Wikipedia contributors. (2025, October 15). Tuskegee Syphilis Study. In Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuskegee_Syphilis_Study

hypotheses.name: OTHER - Unforeseen primary driver
hypotheses.statement: Some unforeseen or currently unspecified factor, or unique combination of factors, is the primary reason the belief that vaccines cause autism persists.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: A yet-unidentified mechanism—social, informational, institutional, or biological—more powerfully explains persistence of the belief than any factor specified in H1-H7.
testable_predictions: Evidence will emerge that does not align with the predictions of H1-H7.
A newly discovered driver shows stronger correlation with vaccine–autism belief prevalence than any factor already proposed.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Institutional distrust & psychological heuristics
hypotheses.statement: The primary reason the belief that vaccines cause autism persists is deep distrust of scientific and governmental institutions, magnified by cognitive biases such as the availability and confirmation heuristics.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: Historic or perceived breaches of trust (e.g., Tuskegee, opioid crisis) trigger a baseline suspicion; once a temporal coincidence between vaccination and autism diagnosis occurs, confirmation bias locks in the narrative.
testable_predictions: Survey data will show higher vaccine–autism belief in populations reporting low trust in government, pharma, and medical authorities.
Interventions that rebuild institutional trust (transparent data sharing, community engagement) will measurably reduce belief prevalence.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Algorithmic misinformation amplification
hypotheses.statement: The belief persists primarily because social-media algorithms and fragmented information ecosystems preferentially surface sensational anti-vaccine content, creating echo chambers that reinforce the autism narrative.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: Engagement-optimized recommendation engines up-rank emotionally charged anti-vaccine posts; repeated exposure produces perceived consensus and social proof, entrenching the belief.
testable_predictions: Removing or down-ranking anti-vaccine content in recommendation algorithms will significantly decrease new adoption of the belief.
Network analyses will reveal highly clustered, algorithmically connected communities sharing vaccine–autism claims.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Cultural & historical anti-establishment narratives
hypotheses.statement: Long-standing cultural narratives of individualism and resistance to perceived elite control are the primary driver of the vaccine–autism belief.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: Anti-establishment subcultures reinterpret vaccine guidance as government overreach; the autism claim functions as a tangible symbol for broader cultural resistance.
testable_predictions: Regions or subcultures with strong anti-establishment identities (e.g., certain political or counter-culture movements) will exhibit higher belief prevalence, independent of education or algorithmic exposure.
Historical spikes in anti-elite sentiment (financial crises, political scandals) will coincide with upticks in vaccine–autism discourse.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Educational and science-literacy gaps
hypotheses.statement: Deficiencies in science education and critical-thinking training are the primary reason the vaccine–autism belief endures.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: Without statistical reasoning skills, temporal correlations are mistaken for causation; limited understanding of immunology and neurodevelopment leaves laypeople vulnerable to simple but incorrect causal stories.
testable_predictions: Belief prevalence will inversely correlate with standardized measures of science literacy and numeracy, controlling for other variables.
Targeted critical-thinking curricula will reduce endorsement of the belief more effectively than trust-building or content-moderation interventions.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Legacy pharmaceutical misconduct fuels rational skepticism
hypotheses.statement: Historical episodes of pharmaceutical and medical misconduct (e.g., Thalidomide, Vioxx) are the primary driver, providing a rational basis for skepticism that morphs into the vaccine–autism belief.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: Salient historical analogues are cited as precedent, leading parents to overgeneralize risk from past drug failures to vaccines; the autism narrative offers a concrete focal point for this rational but misapplied caution.
testable_predictions: Campaigns that transparently acknowledge past misconduct while contrasting vaccine safety records will reduce belief prevalence.
Content analyses will show frequent citation of historical scandals in vaccine–autism advocacy materials.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Theological and moral objections to perceived unnatural intervention
hypotheses.statement: Certain theological worldviews or moral intuitions that view vaccines as unnatural or violating divine design are the primary reason for adopting the autism explanation.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: Belief systems that emphasize purity or divine sovereignty interpret medical intervention as morally suspect; the autism narrative offers an empirical-sounding rationale that aligns with pre-existing moral objections.
testable_predictions: Communities with doctrines stressing bodily purity or divine healing will show higher rates of the belief, even when controlling for education and media exposure.
Framing vaccines as aligned with stewardship or divine providence will reduce belief prevalence in these groups.

hypotheses.name: TRUE - Economic incentives of the alternative-medicine industry
hypotheses.statement: Profit motives within the alternative-medicine and anti-vaccine merchandise ecosystem are the primary driver sustaining the vaccine–autism belief.
hypotheses.mechanism_if_true: Providers of supplements, detox regimens, and anti-vaccine media monetize fear; financial incentives motivate continual production and promotion of autism claims.
testable_predictions: Financial flow analyses will show significant revenue linked to content or products that promote the vaccine–autism narrative.
Exposure to marketing for alternative health products will statistically predict belief adoption more than exposure to non-monetized anti-vaccine content.

items.citation_apa: Deer, B. (2011). Secrets of the MMR scare: how the case against the MMR vaccine was fixed. BMJ, 342, c5347. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.c5347

items.description: BMJ editor Fiona Godlee's 2011 editorial "Institutional and editorial misconduct in the MMR scare" documented how The Lancet and the Royal Free Hospital suppressed whistleblowing and failed to investigate Wakefield's allegations for years, representing a major institutional cover-up.
items.citation_apa: Godlee, F. (2011). Institutional and editorial misconduct in the MMR scare. BMJ, 342, d378. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.d378

items.description: Sarah Boseley's Guardian report from February 2, 2010, described The Lancet's retraction of Wakefield's 1998 MMR-autism paper—12 years after publication—highlighting how peer review and institutional processes failed to detect falsified data and ethical breaches for over a decade.
items.citation_apa: Boseley, S. (2010, February 2). Lancet retracts 'utterly false' MMR paper. The Guardian. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/feb/02/lancet-retracts-mmr-paper

items.description: A 2010 Forbes commentary critiqued The Lancet's retraction notice language as overly technical and opaque, arguing that lack of clear public communication about the retraction hindered public understanding and allowed the vaccine-autism myth to persist.
items.citation_apa: (2010). The Lancet's incomprehensible autism retraction. Forbes. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.forbes.com/sites/sciencebiz/2010/02/02/the-lancets-incomprehensible-autism-retraction/

items.description: Brian Deer's 2020 narrative nonfiction book "The Doctor Who Fooled the World: Science, Deception, and the War on Vaccines" chronicles how Wakefield's fraud and the ensuing media spectacle fueled enduring public affinity for his discredited claims.
items.citation_apa: Deer, B. (2020). The Doctor Who Fooled the World: Science, deception, and the war on vaccines. Johns Hopkins University Press.

items.description: In November 2025, the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases issued a press release condemning a politically-driven CDC website update suggesting vaccines could cause autism, illustrating how policy manipulation by ideologically motivated actors can erode public trust and propagate the myth.
items.citation_apa: National Foundation for Infectious Diseases. (2025, November 21). NFID calls for scientific integrity and transparency in CDC communications. https://www.nfid.org/nfid-calls-for-scientific-integrity-and-transparency-in-cdc-communications/

items.description: Beaveridge (2021) finds that the modern anti-vaccination movement stands on the same pillars as its 19th-century counterpart—namely, fear at its core—exploiting prominent public figures, maintaining false associations of dire vaccine consequences, and emphasizing these through visual media, repetition, and personal narratives, which are more impactful and memorable than statistical characteristics of scientific studies.
items.citation_apa: Beaveridge, K. (2021). From Syphilis to Autism, How the Anti-Vaccination Movement of Today is an Echo of the Past. McGill Journal of Medicine, 19(1). https://doi.org/10.26443/mjm.v19i1.770

items.description: McHugh (2021) reports that Britain’s first anti-vaccination movement (1796–1853) spread fears of blindness, deafness, ulcers, and even “cow mania,” while religious leaders condemned vaccination as blasphemous and historians like Frank Snowden have described political objections as a form of resistance to perceived medical tyranny. Kristin Hussey notes that compulsory vaccination became a “lightning rod” for broader concerns around individual liberty and the role of the state.
items.citation_apa: McHugh, J. (2021, November 14). The world’s first anti-vaccination movement spread fears of half-cow babies. The Washington Post. https://www.washingtonpost.com/history/2021/11/14/smallpox-anti-vaccine-england-jenner/

items.description: The College of Physicians of Philadelphia (2022) documents the Leicester Demonstration March of 1885, in which an estimated 80,000–100,000 anti-vaccinators paraded with banners, a child’s coffin, and an effigy of Jenner to protest compulsory smallpox vaccination, framing their dissent in terms of personal liberty, religious objections, and distrust of medical authority.
items.citation_apa: The College of Physicians of Philadelphia. (2022, April 20). History of Anti-Vaccination Movements. History of Vaccines. https://historyofvaccines.org/vaccines-101/misconceptions-about-vaccines/history-anti-vaccination-movements/

items.description: Durbach (2005) argues that England’s compulsory vaccination laws (1853–1907) provoked a large-scale movement rooted in working-class anxieties over bodily integrity and state overreach, interpreting resistance as a principled protest against what was perceived as insensitive and incompetent poor-law state medicine.
items.citation_apa: Durbach, N. (2005). Bodily Matters: The Anti-Vaccination Movement in England, 1853–1907. Duke University Press.

items.description: Wikipedia contributors (n.d.) note that the 2021 video ‘Medical Racism: The New Apartheid’ leverages historical medical injustices (e.g., Tuskegee Syphilis Study) to lend credibility to current anti-vaccination conspiracies targeting African American and Latin communities, thereby using racialized narratives of past abuses to fuel distrust.
items.citation_apa: Wikipedia contributors. (n.d.). Medical Racism: The New Apartheid. In Wikipedia. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_Racism%3A_The_New_Apartheid

items.description: Offit (2008) exposes how anti-vaccine advocates employ narratives of conspiracy and cover-ups—portraying pharmaceutical and public health institutions as untrustworthy actors—to cast vaccines as dangerous, thus reinforcing cultural distrust and anti-establishment sentiment.
items.citation_apa: Offit, P. A. (2008). Autism's False Prophets: Bad Science, Risky Medicine, and the Search for a Cure. Columbia University Press.

items.description: Virulent: The Vaccine War (2022) argues that modern vaccine hesitancy is driven by values of personal freedom and resistance to perceived unnatural interventions, tracing these themes through historical and contemporary interviews with both opponents and proponents of vaccination.
items.citation_apa: Greidanus, T. (Director). (2022). Virulent: The Vaccine War [Documentary]. Cinema Libre Studio. https://virulentmovie.com

items.description: Analysis of 16,525 caregivers in the SPARK autism research cohort found that 16.5% endorsed vaccines as a possible cause of their child’s autism. Caregivers who believed in vaccine causation disproportionately came from less-educated and lower-income backgrounds, indicating educational gaps in understanding vaccine safety.
items.citation_apa: Fombonne, E., Goin-Kochel, R. P., O’Roak, B. J., & SPARK Consortium. (2020). Beliefs in vaccine as causes of autism among SPARK cohort caregivers. Vaccine, 38(7), 1794–1803. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.vaccine.2019.12.026

items.description: In the 19th wave of the Annenberg Science and Public Health Knowledge (ASAPH) survey (April 18–24, 2024; n=1,522), 24% of U.S. adults did not accept that MMR vaccines do not cause autism and 3% were unsure, highlighting significant knowledge gaps about vaccine-autism misinformation.
items.citation_apa: Annenberg Public Policy Center. (2024, June 3). False Belief in MMR Vaccine-Autism Link Endures as Measles Threat Persists. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://www.annenbergpublicpolicycenter.org/false-belief-in-mmr-vaccine-autism-link-endures-as-measles-threat-persists/

items.description: Cross-sectional web-based survey (May–July 2021; n=322) of parents of children with ASD found that while 35% intended to vaccinate their child against COVID-19, positive vaccine beliefs—but not provider trust—were associated with intention, suggesting that additional education is needed to bolster vaccine confidence in this population.
items.citation_apa: Choi, K., Becerra-Culqui, T., Bhakta, B., Bruxvoort, K., & Coleman, K. J. (2022). Parent intentions to vaccinate children with autism spectrum disorder against COVID-19. Journal of Pediatric Nursing, 63, 108–110. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.pedn.2021.11.019

items.description: A 2006 survey of 1,726 U.S. adults found that 42% of respondents were ‘somewhat distrusting’ to ‘strongly distrusting’ of pharmaceutical companies, and 96% expressed concern about adverse reactions to prescription drugs taken as directed, reflecting heightened public wariness following the Vioxx (rofecoxib) safety scandal.
items.citation_apa: Olsen, A. K., & Whalen, M. D. (2009). Public perceptions of the pharmaceutical industry and drug safety: Implications for the pharmacovigilance professional and the culture of safety. Drug Safety, 32(10), 805–810. https://doi.org/10.2165/11316620-000000000-00000

items.description: A 2017 Pew Research Center survey found that only 13% of Americans trust information from pharmaceutical industry leaders a lot about childhood vaccines, compared to 55% who trust medical scientists a lot, indicating a significant trust deficit towards vaccine makers.
items.citation_apa: Pew Research Center. (2017, February 2). Public trust in medical scientists and their research on childhood vaccines. Pew Research Center. Retrieved from https://www.pewresearch.org/science/2017/02/02/public-trust-in-medical-scientists-and-their-research-on-childhood-vaccines-2/

items.description: In April 2012, Merck Sharp & Dohme pled guilty to misbranding Vioxx and was sentenced to pay a $321.6 million criminal fine and $628.4 million in civil settlements for illegal promotion and concealment of cardiovascular risks, underscoring corporate practices that undermine public trust in pharmaceutical safety.
items.citation_apa: U.S. Department of Justice. (2012, April 19). U.S. pharmaceutical company Merck Sharp & Dohme sentenced in connection with unlawful promotion of Vioxx [Press release]. Retrieved from https://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-pharmaceutical-company-merck-sharp-dohme-sentenced-connection-unlawful-promotion-vioxx

items.description: Revelation of the 1932–1972 Tuskegee Syphilis Study, in which U.S. Public Health Service researchers knowingly withheld effective treatment from Black men, has been cited as a foundational cause of medical mistrust among African Americans, contributing historically to vaccine hesitancy in the community.
items.citation_apa: Wikipedia contributors. (2025, October 15). Tuskegee Syphilis Study. In Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Retrieved January 19, 2026, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuskegee_Syphilis_Study

items.description: Qualitative interviews with 137 U.S. adults during early COVID-19 vaccine rollout revealed that most participants’ distrust in vaccination stemmed from negative pre-pandemic experiences with medical institutions, including the pharmaceutical industry, indicating that legacy misconduct shaped current vaccine views.
items.source_name: RSF: The Russell Sage Foundation Journal of the Social Sciences
items.citation_apa: Casselman-Hontalas, A., Adams-Santos, D., & Watkins-Hayes, C. (2024). Discourses of distrust: How lack of trust in the U.S. health-care system shaped COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy. RSF: The Russell Sage Foundation Journal of the Social Sciences, 10(4), 154–172. https://doi.org/10.7758/RSF.2024.10.4.07

items.description: Edelman’s 2018 Trust Barometer recorded the largest-ever one-year drop in U.S. trust for the pharmaceutical sector, falling 13 points from 51% to 38%—a decline attributed in part to high-profile safety and pricing controversies like the Vioxx withdrawal.
items.citation_apa: Bulik, B. S. (2018, June 13). Trust pharma? Not so much, annual survey shows, with biggest loss ever. Fierce Pharma. Retrieved from https://www.fiercepharma.com/marketing/pharma-trust-plummets-u-s-consumers-annual-edelman-survey-biggest-dive-to-date

items.description: Dr. Meryl Nass, board member of the Alliance for Human Research Protection, argues that over $38 billion in pharmaceutical industry settlements—including $4.85 billion for Vioxx and $2.3 billion for Pfizer’s off-label marketing—has 'earned' the industry’s low public trust, which paradoxically coexists with high vaccine acceptance.
items.citation_apa: Nass, M. (2019, March 28). Why Americans don’t trust vaccine makers [Op‐Ed]. Alliance for Human Research Protection. Retrieved from https://ahrp.org/why-americans-dont-trust-vaccine-makers/
